experience: You and Josiah both know Dieter Otte and James Palmer
You both worked at Northern Arizona University
Josiah worked at Northern Arizona University after you started
As a software developer at Semper Valens Solutions, I've created web pages and workflow tools for the All-Source and Single-Source DCGS-A teams.

As a lab  teaching assistant and grader, I guided students through digital logic, circuits and semiconductor labs by explaining necessary concepts and helping with debugging using Multimeters, Oscilloscopes, Frequency Generators, etc. I also developed FPGA labs on the Quartus II software with another TA to replace outdated labs as well as debugged a piece of software written in Java for a lab on timing diagrams.
Columbia University in the City of New York

As an undergraduate researcher at Columbia university, I researched topics in wireless networks as a part of the Center for Integrated Access Networks Research Experience for Undergraduates (CIAN REU). While there, I tested a wireless node selection algorithm on a large scale wireless test bed called ORBIT as well as parallelized a python script across a cluster that data mined packet capture files from the ORBIT tests. I used Git as version control for iterations of the python script and ORBIT tests. I presented my results at the end of the summer to the faculty, PhD students, and other undergraduate researchers.

As a D&A summer intern, I primarily developed a recipe transfer system for a variety of machines using Excel, VBA, RSLogix5000 and FactoryTalk ME. While there, I also worked with a sponsor to design general process code for a Next Generation Laser machine and researched and tested the abilities of Yokogawa’s data acquisition devices. Towards the end of the internship, I attended a training course on AutoCADe and helped another intern develop schematics afterwards.At the end of the summer, I gave a PowerPoint slide presentation on these accomplishments to the Design & Automation Engineers.
Columbia University in the City of New York
Graduate Research with Nima Mesgarani, Tesla Scholar

While at Columbia University, I explored voice recognition techniques using a Microsoft neural network that mapped signals to phonemes. I designed MATLAB code to test the network’s resilience to different noise types with varying levels of noise.

summary: I am a recent graduate from Columbia University in Electrical Engineering with a focus in Neuroengineering.I have a great deal of interest in emerging technologies, communications and signal processing, wireless networks, neural networks, and brain-machine interfaces. I hope to contribute my knowledge and skills to help develop cutting-edge technology in these and related fields.Languages: C/C++, Java, MATLAB, Assembly, VHDL, Python. Software: ModelSim, Simulink, MATLAB, Altera Quartus, Ecilpse, AutoCADe, Git, Microsoft Office productsPlatforms: 68k, MSP430, ORBIT wireless testbed
